positive.review: It might be a copy of Forza Horizon, but what they put in the game is quite interesting, like the history of Bugatti and other brands. The game is also very beautiful. People say that the Ubisoft launcher is buggy, but I didn't have any problems. I liked the game and I recommend it.

The vibes? Immaculate.
The visuals? So gorgeous it made me feel bad for every wall I accidentally introduced my car to.
The handling? Smooth enough to make me think maybe I can actually drive in real life. (Spoiler: I cannot.)

It’s chaotic, stylish and somehow turns every playlist race into a wild showcase of vehicles where they get their own spotlight moment.

In short: I loved it. Would floor the accelerator into paradise again.
9/10 This can't be a Ubisoft Game

Amazing game 9/10 the most time, though the engine still being capped to 60 frames for gameplay reasons is still a bummer.

(For the Steam Awards 2025, I voted motorfest for the labor of love category due to the game getting content every week, with amazing effort put into each.)

If you came to this game disappointed by the fact that Forza Horizon 5 turned out to be a lazy reskin of Forza Horizon 4 without new ideas and features, a boring map, and dripfeeding you cars conveniently cut from the game beforehand, then you've come to the right place. Don't get me wrong, FH5 is a fantastic!!! game if it's your first Forza Horizon, but for a fan of the series, it's quite disappointing in terms of missed opportunities and lazy practices in post-release support. 

In my opinion, Motorfest is better than FH5 in every way except of graphics, it's not bad by any means, FH5 just has a more technologically advanced engine, but Motorfest wins with vibe and style!!! The map is infinitely better, the visual customization of the cars is incredibly cool, the cars feel like cars and not like collectibles, i don't know how to explain it, you want to drive them, not just collect them in the garage, they feel more weighty and the first-person camera is done gorgeously, with slight shaking and all sorts of animations of the character's hands, and not like in Forza where the crab-like hands are made like "insert a steering wheel into them". 

And what always turned me off about Forza in terms of customization is that visual customization is tied to the car's characteristics... you put on your favorite bumper... that's it, your car is no longer meta, but here visual tuning is untied from the characteristics, and therefore it brings pleasure, and you don't need to be a mechanic to stick on your favorite body kit. The game also features an interesting reimagining of playlists, where the races within them are linked by a single theme with tons of activities. 

Developers support the game with free updates featuring new playlists, cars, map expansions (and not like in FH, where you have to load each new area separately) and features like chase mode. That's why I give the game a solid 9/10. It has some bugs, it has some flaws in the multiplayer component, and the engine is limited to 60 fps, but for me these are minor issues. For me, this game beats the latest iteration of FH.

The Crew Motorfest a.k.a TCM
This game is the best arcade/simcade racing game I have ever played, the only game that I could consider to be on par is Burnout Paradise
Motorfest

The game is built upon "playlists" which is more or less a set of races under the same theme. I think rn there are 27 playlists and later today when Season 8 drops another one will be added.
It takes roughly about 30 hrs to complete all the playlists, it used to be much shorter bcs the game didnt have as many playlists as it does now when I started playing which was April 27th 2024 towards the end of Season 3.
These playlists are basically your "Career", the game doesnt have a story or a real career in that sense u just do these playlists and thats it. It felt very weird the first time I played it bcs of exactly this.

As for online, the game is very restricted. There are only two PvP gamemodes, "The Grand Race" and "Demolition Derby" 
"The Grand Race" is a huge 28 player race which takes anywhere between 7 to 10 minutes to complete. The twist is that the race is divided into 3 different sections where u swap between disciplines midrace. This swap is most of the time seamless and I love "The Grand Race" bcs its a unique concept and its hella fun.
"Demolition Derby" on the other hand is more or less a joke within the community, nobody competitive plays this as it isnt even a race. 
DD is just like a battle royale gamemode where u pickup powerups and try to crash into the other players with specialized DD cars that are also extremely slow, all while the "circle of death" is shrinking. Its not terrible but its neglected by the devs and has basically been the same throughout all seasons.

There are 2 other "PvP" things to do that arent races but still competitions.
"The Summit" and "The Custom Show"

"The Summit" is a 6 event + 3 feats weekly competition where each event gets u points from 0 to 157 850, which is the maximum possible amount of points for 1 event. There are 4 reward levels: Platinum, Gold, Silver and Bronze. Nowadays Platinum is ridiculously easy to get so u pretty much get all rewards every week. Its basically like Forza Horizon's "Horizon Playlist" but executed in a much better way with points and far less events that u have to do and the rewards are actually things u want and not just some random garbage car. (most of the time atleast)

"The Custom Show" is also a weekly competition except there is no racing u just register a car and hope u get votes to win stuff, u can vote for yourself every 12 hrs tho so u can just get plat yourself

There is also "The Main Stage" which lasts for the whole month and u just get XP and levels and u get stuff with level 50 being the highest rn with no point in going any further then that.


PROS:
Physics are insanely good for high speed racing

Graphics are absolute peak, probably the best looking racing game of all time

The Summit is PEAK

CONS:
Physics are bad for going relatively slow (more or less everything under 200 km/h)

The price of Crew Credits, Crew Credits or "CC" is the ingame currency that can only be bought with real money and u can buy visual customization called "Vanities" for your vehicles with CC. The price of CC is more or less 5€ or 10€ for one single vanity. Considering there is about 1.3K vanities thats alot of money if u want them all.

Every single season either retains current bugs or adds more bugs to the game

Very often I was positively surprised by this game but at the same time with each next hour I feel that this game is lacking depth. To put it simply new players need to play this game lots of hours to even know how to compete with other players and in leaderboards. It might seem obvious but the problem is that this game doesn't invite new players to compete against other players and to play with friends. So most new players (possibly me too) will play some playlists (which are really good, maybe perfect for new game feature) and when they will finish most of them game will simply end. 

This game doesn't have lots of great ideas, it's not like every new thing you see is great. There's a challenge to drive with a car you win for 10 min on highway during night. Another tasks are done only at "Dusk" or "Dawn" and there's no way to tell exactly when this will happen because there's no timer. Instead of doing a few things in a row you wait for this certain moment to take some photo. Same with upgrading cars, you get lots of parts for car category you use (street 2 for example) but it takes lots of time to get those parts and any other category of vehicles is completely empty. There's lots of travelling around whole map because at the beginning there's no fast travel (each next playlist unlocks one place) and after first few playlists I had over 400 miles driven possibly only in freeroam. For such game design this map is very monotonous. I know every inch of 1 mile circle around every fast travel point. Reward boxes respawn in same places after log out or few in game days - I found maybe 10 such places, maybe more, finding them after some time gets repetitive. Not to mention some grandpa telling us stories about nothing for 1 hour straight and giving us at least 24 reasons to have photogenic epilepsy unlocked or simply yelling at him. What I mean is that this game is super creative but many of those ideas aren't optimized.

So why 4/5? I didn't play previous Crew games, here racing can be really fun. AI at expert difficulty is just right to keep me focused with a few examples of real challenge. Lots of nice cars. Nice boat races, nice combination of different vehicles, after a few hundred hours I might actually stand a chance to win some awards in multiplayer.

The Crew Motorfest is a challenger for Forza Horizon leadership but as such this game from the start loses "innovation points". Every repetition in this game feels worser than in FH because it's already repeated from FH. It didn't beat Forza in any way in my opinion but some ideas I saw in TCM are well worth implementing in new games (themed, diversed races, climatic intros etc.). I can recommend this game for some weekend players but rather with Ubisoft+ subscription. There's at least 50 hours of content worth seeing, the rest depends on whether you'll like driving model and cars presented in the game. They are nice

[b]The Crew Motorfest – A Stunning Celebration of Cars, Speed, and Style[/b]

[i]The Crew Motorfest[/i] is an absolute blast from start to finish. Ubisoft has taken everything fans loved about open-world racing and pushed it to a whole new level with vibrant locations, gorgeous lighting, and a festival vibe that keeps the energy high every second you play.

The driving feels smooth, responsive, and incredibly fun—whether you're drifting down mountain roads, tearing through beaches, or weaving through city streets. The variety of vehicles is fantastic, and each one feels distinct and satisfying to control. The playlists system is a standout, turning every event into a themed adventure, from classic racing culture to modern motorsport experiences.

What really makes this game shine is the atmosphere. The world feels alive, the soundtrack amps up every race, and the festival setting makes even casual cruising exciting. Whether you're competing, exploring, or customizing your dream ride, there's always something new to discover.

[i]The Crew Motorfest[/i] is a love letter to car enthusiasts and a must-play for anyone who enjoys high-speed open-world racing. Fun, stylish, and endlessly replayable — it's easily one of the most enjoyable racing experiences out there.

I can’t, in good conscience, recommend this game to anyone expecting a true continuation of The Crew series. However, I’ll try to be as fair and balanced as possible in my assessment.

Pros

• Visuals
The game looks fantastic. Environments, vehicles, and effects are all beautifully done and easily among the best in the series.

• Driving Physics
The racing feels surprisingly lifelike. Every setting adjustment genuinely impacts how the car behaves. ABS is especially impressive, reacting in a way that feels close to real-world behavior. Even aerodynamic modifications noticeably affect performance.

• Story
The narrative is engaging and well-constructed, offering a solid reason to progress through the content.

• UI/UX
The user interface is clean, intuitive, and easy to navigate—no unnecessary clutter or confusion.

• Off-Road Racing
Off-road segments actually feel like proper off-roading. While the sliding is a bit exaggerated for my taste, it’s still manageable and fun overall.

Cons

• Airplane Handling
Flying is, frankly, terrible. There are barely any flying or acrobatic races, and when you do encounter them, they feel frustrating and poorly designed.

• Boat Gameplay
Boating doesn’t fare much better. While the water feels smoother than before, there are very few races or activities tied to boats, making this mode feel neglected.

• Off-Road Bikes & Quads
Motorcycles, stunt bikes, and quads handle almost as poorly as planes. Their controls feel unwieldy and awkward, making them more frustrating than fun.

• Lack of Community Races
As far as I could tell, community-made races are completely absent, which removes a major element of replayability from previous titles.

Overall

The game can be fun, but compared to The Crew and The Crew 2, The Crew Motorfest feels like an entirely different experience—one that leans more toward a reskinned Forza than a true successor to the series. Fans expecting the familiar formula may end up disappointed.

These reviews are:
either A: rigged 
or B: made by people with very poor expectations of a finished game.
The few things this game did right are:
- Graphics: They are not the worst or the best, but they can do. Characters are aweful though, faces look like their designed after monkeys instead of humans.
- Performance: It runs fine(on Linux that means once you get it running).
- Cars: Plenty to choose from.
- Content: it looks like it has a lot of content to go through.
Everything else is just poorly designed, broken, or plain bugged.
- racing line: It will go through walls and off track... Terribly broken.
- guidelines: They're a joke. It makes you drop down from mountains and cliffs to reach the road at the bottom. Sometimes they break so hard, it can only show a straight line to the objective. No matter if you're in the right vehicle or not.
- vehicles, seriously, get rid of boats, motorcycles and planes all together, they're nothing but a joke.
- controls are the worst, compare it to any game in the last 40 years, never have you driven with controls shitty as these.
- popups, during races, menus, free drive, popups are all around. Challenge here, Rival there, feats... I'm heading for my next destination, please let me get there. Heck while typing this review a popup showed up across my screen, but surely it disappeared when I switched to the window. Good stuff.
- NPC drivers in races: They follow the racing line. Remember what I said about the racing line? Crashing into walls and going off track on weird places? Guess what, NPCs just drive themselves in to the walls and and go off track.
- NPC drivers in free roam. There are 2 kind of NPC drivers, normal slow traffic, they're everywhere and always in the wrong places. Then there are obnoxious 'replayers' as Ubi calls them. Ghosts of cars racing, often showing up in groups of 10 or more cars, blasting through everything. I guess it's a pro you can turn these drivers off.
- Feats: small objectives in free roam. Those are things like slalom courses or getting away from uhm, something? So, remember those slow traffic nps? They are everywhere, blocking the slalom routes and blocking you from getting up to speed to get away. Don't be surprised when you reset 15 times just because these npcs keep you from getting anywhere.
- Physics are the worst. They seem totally random. One of the feats are the so called long jumps. I was doing one and simply aiming for the target got me 20 meters short, no matter how fast I was driving. It felt like the game just decided at points that I had covered enough distance and then dropped me straight down to the ground. I got annoyed and didn't aim anymore. That's when the game decided my angle was now good enough or something and immediately got me 100 meters over the target. Same speed as before, just not pointing at the target as well as before. I was glad I got it done. But it was ridiculous how it got done.
- Stash: after a few races you find out the upgrades you win are send to a stash'. That stash has very low inventory and then you find out how deep the game has sunk: you get to play a merge-3 game to clear your stash. But only if you have made enough currencies.
Now that I've played this game a bit, I also looked it up on the reddits and discords and such... guess what, most of these bugs and funny things were there from the start. As I play on Linux, I highly doubt the SteamDeck rating. Normal Proton, as well as a bunch of forks, do not even get the Ubisoft Connect services running.
I want to explore the islands and see and experience more, but the game makes it very hard to actually enjoy it. I found myself multiple times just quitting mid-objective because of the many things mentioned, not willing to be bothered with the same bug or quirk over and over again.

A few more hours has gone into it, not as much as is shown, since Steam thinks the game is running while it's just the stupid Ubisoft Launcher. Tried some PVP... There is no serious PVP in this game. Zero! There's a grand race, with not just 1 car, nooo, the race is divided in 3 parts with different cars for each track. Terrible races with what looks like random tracks, as sometimes solid objects are in the middle of tracks. Then there's a destruction derby in teams. Which is equally terrible. This is the perfect example of what you get if you put everything in the same game, nothing is good, I'd even go as far as nothing is medium, as everything is done better in games < €20.

    [*] a really immersive and realistic first-person cockpit view. the way the camera shakes, pans, bobs, and generally moves around, combined with the stellar steering wheel animations - a high degree of rotation and realistic maneuvering (the way the character manually attempts to keep it under control) at both low and high speeds, and other immersive bits (like the character occasionally resting their arm on the window, or adjusting the rear-view mirror), all make cruising around super satisfying
    [*] more realistic sounds (vehicles, but also especially weather-related ones, particularly so thunder and rain)
    [*] more realistic weather-related visuals - the difference between any two distinct weather conditions are really profound which makes for consistently gorgeous presentations.
[/list]
